{{good article}} {{Use mdy dates|date=July 2015}} {{Infobox video game | title = Far Cry 4 | image = Far Cry 4 box art.jpg | developer = [[Ubisoft Montreal]]{{efn|Additional work by [[Ubisoft Toronto]], [[Red Storm Entertainment]], [[Ubisoft Shanghai]], and [[Ubisoft Kiev]].<ref>{{cite web |url=http://blog.ubi.com/far-cry-4-release-date-kyrat/ |title=Far Cry 4 – Welcome to Kyrat |last=Steinman |first=Gary |work=UbiBlog |publisher=[[Ubisoft]] |date=May 15, 2014 |accessdate=October 21, 2014 }}</ref>}} | publisher = [[Ubisoft]] | director = {{Unbulleted list|[[Alex Hutchinson (video game director)|Alex Hutchinson]]|Patrik Méthé}} | producer = Cedric Decelle | programmer = {{Unbulleted list|Cedric Decelle|David Chabot}} | artist = Jean-Alexis Doyon | writer = {{Unbulleted list|Mark Thompson|Li Kuo|[[Lucien Soulban]]}} | composer = [[Cliff Martinez]] | series = ''[[Far Cry]]'' | engine = | platforms = {{Unbulleted list|[[Microsoft Windows]]|[[PlayStation 3]]|[[PlayStation 4]]|[[Xbox 360]]|[[Xbox One]]}} | released = November 18, 2014 | genre = [[Action-adventure game|Action-adventure]], [[first-person shooter]] | modes = [[Single-player video game|Single-player]], [[Multiplayer video game|multiplayer]] }}
'''''Far Cry 4''''' is an [[Action-adventure game|action-adventure]] [[first-person shooter]] video game developed by [[Ubisoft Montreal]] and published by [[Ubisoft]] for the [[PlayStation 3]], [[PlayStation 4]], [[Xbox 360]], [[Xbox One]], and [[Microsoft Windows]]. It is the successor to the 2012 video game ''[[Far Cry 3]]'', and the fourth main installment in the ''[[Far Cry]]'' series. The game was released on November 18, 2014.
The game takes place in Kyrat, a fictional [[Himalayas|Himalayan]] country. The main story follows Ajay Ghale, a young Kyrati-American, as he is caught in a civil war involving Kyrat's Royal Army, controlled by tyrannical king Pagan Min, and a rebel movement called the Golden Path. Gameplay focuses on combat and exploration; players battle enemy soldiers and dangerous wildlife using a wide array of weapons. The game features many elements found in [[role-playing game]]s, such as a branching storyline, and side quests. The game also features a map editor, a co-operative multiplayer mode, and an asymmetrical competitive multiplayer mode.
Announced in May 2014, development on ''Far Cry 4'' began immediately after the shipment of ''[[Assassin's Creed III]]'' in late 2012. The team originally intended to develop a direct sequel to ''Far Cry 3'' that continues ''3''<nowiki/>'s story, but the idea was later scrapped and the team decided to develop a new setting and new story for the game. Certain aspects of ''Far Cry 4'' were inspired by the [[Nepalese Civil War]], and the costume of the game's antagonist Pagan Min was inspired by Japanese films ''[[Ichi the Killer (film)|Ichi the Killer]]'' and ''[[Brother (2000 film)|Brother]]''. The game's competitive multiplayer was created by [[Red Storm Entertainment]] while the Shangri-La segments in the campaign were handled by [[Ubisoft Toronto]].
''Far Cry 4'' was met with a mostly positive critical reception upon release. Critics praised the open world design, visuals, soundtrack, and characters, particularly antagonist Pagan Min, as well as new gameplay additions and the wealth of content. However, some critics disliked the story and found the game too similar to its predecessor. The game was a commercial success, selling seven million copies by the end of 2014, and was the biggest launch in the franchise's history. Several releases of downloadable content were subsequently published. A successor, ''[[Far Cry 5]]'', was released on March 27, 2018.
==Gameplay== ''Far Cry 4'' is a [[first-person perspective|first-person]] [[action-adventure game|action-adventure]] game. Players assume control of Ajay Ghale, a Kyrati-American who is on a quest to spread his deceased mother's ashes in the [[fictional country]] of Kyrat. Throughout the game, players can run, leap, and crouch, and have the ability to use weapons including shotguns, crossbows, sniper rifles, mines, throwing knives, bows, flamethrowers, and rocket launchers.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=XBjYmryqBrc|title=Far Cry 4 – The Gun Show|work=[[YouTube]]|publisher=[[GameSpot]]|date=November 23, 2014|accessdate=August 25, 2015}}</ref> The game allows players to take cover to avoid gunfights and to perform melee takedowns from above or up-close.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.shacknews.com/article/87165/far-cry-4-review-surviving-war-and-wildlife|title=Far Cry 4 Review: Surviving War and Wildlife|first=Steven|last=Wong|work=[[Shacknews]]|date=November 18, 2014|accessdate=August 25, 2015}}</ref> Unlike previous installments in the series, ''Far Cry 4'' gives players the ability to kick objects and the ability to hide the corpses of enemies.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.eurogamer.net/articles/2014-06-10-far-cry-4-gameplay-footage-shows-co-op-grapple-hook-kicking|title=Far Cry 4 gameplay footage shows co-op, grapple hook, kicking|first=Robert|last=Purchase|work=[[Eurogamer]]|date=June 10, 2014|accessdate=August 25, 2015}}</ref> [[File:Far Cry 4 gameplay screenshot 1.jpg|thumb|right|In ''Far Cry 4'', players have the ability to ride on elephants.]] Players can use a variety of methods to approach missions. For instance, players can utilize stealth to evade enemies and complete objectives without being noticed, or they also have the option to assault enemies with firearms and vehicles. The player-character is equipped with a digital camera, which allows him to mark and highlight all visible enemies, animals, and loots. Players are also able to ride on elephants,<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.primagames.com/games/far-cry-4/tips/how-ride-elephants-far-cry-4-elephant-rider-skill|title=How to Ride Elephants in Far Cry 4 – Elephant Rider Skill|first=Christopher|last=Buffa|work=[[Prima Games]]|accessdate=November 5, 2015}}</ref> which serve as tank-like offensive weapons.<ref name="elephant">{{cite web|url=http://www.pcgamer.com/far-cry-4-hands-on-roaming-free-in-kyrat/|title=Far Cry 4 hands-on: roaming free in Kyrat|first=Shaun|last=Prescott |date=October 15, 2014|accessdate=August 25, 2015|work=[[PC Gamer]]}}</ref> Players can throw bait towards enemies, which attracts nearby wildlife that is hostile to both the player and enemies. Players can also hunt and skin animals.<ref name="PCTrailer">{{cite web|url=http://www.pcgamer.com/far-cry-4-101-trailer-is-all-you-need-to-know-about-ubisofts-upcoming-shooter/|title=Far Cry 4 101 trailer is all you need to know about Ubisoft's upcoming shooter|first=Andy|last=Chalk|work=[[PC Gamer]]|date=November 12, 2014|accessdate=August 25, 2015}}</ref>
The game features an [[open world]] environment that is free for players to explore. It features several environments, including forests, rivers, and mountains.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.ign.com/articles/2014/08/15/gamescom-2014-far-cry-4-glimpse-into-kyrat-trailer-rewind-theater|title=Gamescom 2014: Far Cry 4 Glimpse Into Kyrat Trailer Rewind Theatre|first=Tate|last=Fiebing|work=[[IGN]]|date=August 15, 2014|accessdate=August 25, 2015}}</ref> To allow players to travel between places faster, the game features various vehicles, including buggies, trucks, and water vehicles like [[speedboats]]. Players can drive and shoot at the same time, and can enable auto-drive, in which the game's [[artificial intelligence]] takes over the role of controlling the vehicle and guides players to their objectives.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.eurogamer.net/articles/2014-12-02-moving-targets-the-scattergun-politics-of-far-cry-4|title=Moving targets: the scattergun politics of Far Cry 4|first=Edwin|last=Evans-Thirlwell|date=December 2, 2014|accessdate=August 25, 2015|work=[[Eurogamer]]}}</ref> Players can also hijack other vehicles while driving. The Buzzer, an aerial, helicopter-like vehicle, is introduced in the game, allowing players to gain a tactical advantage from the air.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.gameinformer.com/games/far_cry_4/b/playstation4/archive/2014/06/11/taking-down-a-fortress-with-a-friend-in-far-cry-4.aspx|title=Taking Down A Fortress With A Friend In Far Cry 4|first=Matt|last=Bertz|work=[[Game Informer]]|date=June 11, 2014|accessdate=August 25, 2015}}</ref> Parachutes, wingsuits, and grappling hooks are also featured in the game; these items help players swing across cliffs and quickly navigate the environment.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.hardcoregamer.com/2014/12/16/the-many-minor-missteps-of-far-cry-4/123608/|title=The Many (Minor) Missteps of Far Cry 4|first=Thomas|last=Elia|date=December 16, 2014|accessdate=August 25, 2015|work=[[Hardcore Gamer]]}}</ref> Parts of the game take place in [[Shangri-La]], a mystical dreamland where players battle demons as the Kyrati warrior Kalinag. While in Shangri-La, players are accompanied by an injured tiger which serves as their companion. Players can issue commands to the tiger, which assists them in battle.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.engadget.com/2014/08/18/far-cry-4-crouching-tiger-hidden-blood-dragon/|title=Far Cry 4: Crouching tiger, hidden Blood Dragon|first=Ludwig|last= Kietzmann |work=[[Joystiq]]|date=August 18, 2014|accessdate=August 25, 2015}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.ign.com/articles/2014/08/14/gamescom-2014-5-reasons-far-cry-4-looks-like-a-trip-worth-taking|work=[[IGN]]|title=Gamescom 2014: 5 Reason Far Cry 4 Looks Like A Trip Worth Taking|first=Tristan|last=Oglivie|date=August 14, 2014|accessdate=August 25, 2015}}</ref>
The game world is divided into two halves: North and South Kyrat. Players start in South Kyrat and are free to explore it almost immediately, but can only unlock North Kyrat over the course of the story. The map is progressively opened by liberating bell towers, freeing them from Pagan Min's influence and allowing the Golden Path to expand. These towers help players reveal new areas and mark new locations of interest on the map.<ref name="Tips">{{cite web|url=http://kotaku.com/tips-for-playing-far-cry-4-1661679705|title=Tips for playing Far Cry 4|date=November 24, 2014|accessdate=August 25, 2015|first=Yannick |last=LeJacq|work=[[Kotaku]]}}</ref> The world is scattered with outposts controlled by Pagan Min, which can be infiltrated by players. Four larger outposts, or fortresses, can also be found, and feature stronger defenses and more difficult combinations of enemies. If players successfully liberate these outposts, they will serve as fast-travel points, allowing quick navigation through the game's world. Additional missions and quests also become available.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.gamesradar.com/10-ways-stay-alive-far-cry-4-deadly-world/|work=[[GamesRadar]]|title=10 ways to stay alive in Far Cry 4's deadly world|first=David|last=Roberts|date=October 14, 2014|accessdate=August 25, 2015}}</ref> There are many side-missions that can be completed, including hostage rescues, bomb disposal quests, and hunting missions. The collected animals' parts can then be used for crafting new pouches and belts.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://gamingbolt.com/far-cry-4-interview-world-size-crafting-side-quests-and-more|title=Far Cry 4 Interview: World Size, Crafting, Side Quests And More|first=Rashid|last=Sayed |date=September 10, 2014|accessdate=August 25, 2015|work=Gaming Bolt}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.vg1247.com/2014/10/06/far-cry-4-karma-chaos-kyrat/|title=Far Cry 4: karma and chaos in Kyrat|first=Matt|last=Martin|work=[[VG247]]|date=October 6, 2014|accessdate=August 26, 2015|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20151208074728/http://www.vg1247.com/2014/10/06/far-cry-4-karma-chaos-kyrat/|archivedate=December 8, 2015|df=mdy-all}}</ref>
Like its predecessors, the game features some [[role-playing video game|role-playing]] elements. Players can earn experience points by completing missions and defeating enemies, and these experience points can then be spent on performance boosts and upgrades. There are two sets of abilities for players to choose from, called The Tiger and The Elephant. The Tiger upgrades mainly improve players' offensive abilities, while The Elephant upgrades improve players' defensive skills. A variety of random events and hostile encounters take place throughout the game; for example, the player may unexpectedly be attacked by an eagle, be hit by a car, or witness an animal attack. Players can accumulate karma by performing kind actions towards the rebels, such as by assisting them in battles when they are attacked by wildlife or enemies. Doing so will give players discounts when purchasing new items at trading posts, and will allow players to call in support and back-up from members of the Golden Path.<ref name="PCTrailer"/><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.eurogamer.net/articles/2014-10-14-why-ajay-ghale-isnt-the-real-star-of-far-cry-4|title=Why Ajay Ghale isn't the real star of Far Cry 4|first=Aoife|last=Wilson|work=[[Eurogamer]]|date=October 14, 2015|accessdate=August 25, 2015}}</ref> Players can also gain experience by collecting items like masks, propaganda posters, and [[prayer wheel]]s.<ref name="Tips"/> There is also an Arena mode, in which players battle human enemies and animals for additional experience points and rewards.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.gamespot.com/articles/far-cry-4s-arena-mode-is-a-gladiator-style-humans-/1100-6422371/|title=Far Cry 4's Arena Mode Is a Gladiator-Style, Humans vs. Animals Affair|first=Eddie|last=Makuch|work=[[GameSpot]]|date=September 17, 2014|accessdate=August 25, 2015}}</ref>
===Multiplayer=== ''Far Cry 4'' features a [[co-operative gameplay|co-operative multiplayer]] mode known as "Guns for Hire", which supports up to two players. The mode is separated from the game's campaign, and players are free to explore the game's world, defeat enemies, and infiltrate outposts with their companion.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://blog.us.playstation.com/2014/06/09/far-cry-4-co-op-modes-detailed/|title=Far Cry 4 Co-op Modes Detailed|first=Kim|last=Belair|date=June 9, 2015|accessdate=August 25, 2015|work=[[PlayStation Blog]]}}</ref> In addition to the co-operative mode, players can gain access to several competitive multiplayer modes which have an asymmetrical structure. Players play as either a Rakshasa or a Golden Path member. The Rakshasa are equipped with bows and arrows, and have the ability to teleport and to summon wildlife to assist them, while Golden Path members are equipped with guns and explosives, and have access to armored vehicles.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.eurogamer.net/articles/2014-06-12-heres-how-far-cry-4-co-op-works-if-you-dont-have-the-game|title=Here's how Far Cry 4 co-op works if you don't have the game|first=Jeffery|last=Matulef|work=[[Eurogamer]]|date=June 13, 2014|accessdate=August 25, 2015}}</ref> Known as "Battles of Kyrat", players fight against each other in three modes, called Outpost, Propaganda, and Demon Mask.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.pcgamer.com/far-cry-4s-pvp-multiplayer-mode-mixes-magic-with-elephants-guns-with-stealth/|title=Far Cry 4's PvP multiplayer mode mixes magic with elephants, guns with stealth|first=Tom|last=Sykes|date=October 31, 2014|accessdate=August 25, 2015|work=[[PC Gamer]]}}</ref> ''Far Cry 4'' also contains a Map Editor that allows users to create and share custom content. Similar to that of ''Far Cry 3'', players can create their maps by customizing landscapes, and by placing buildings, trees, wildlife, and vehicles.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.gamespot.com/videos/far-cry-4-level-editor-trick-jumps-death-pits-and-/2300-6422472/|title=Far Cry 4 Level Editor – Trick Jumps, Death Pits and Noah's Ark|work=[[GameSpot]]|date=November 28, 2014|accessdate=August 26, 2014|first=Mary |last=Kish}}</ref> However, the Map Editor did not support competitive multiplayer levels at launch.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.eurogamer.net/articles/2014-11-14-far-cry-4-map-editor-doesnt-support-competitive-multiplayer|title=Far Cry 4 map editor doesn't support competitive multiplayer|first=Tom|last=Phillips|work=[[Eurogamer]]|date=November 14, 2014|accessdate=August 26, 2015}}</ref> Multiplayer support was added to the game on February 3, 2015.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.gameinformer.com/b/news/archive/2015/02/03/far-cry-4-update-adds-co-op-custom-maps.aspx|title=Far Cry 4 Update Adds Co-op Custom Maps|first=Kyle|last=Hilliard|work=[[Game Informer]]|date=February 3, 2015|accessdate=November 3, 2015}}</ref>
==Synopsis==
===Premise=== The story was inspired by the ten-year-long [[Nepalese Civil War|Maoist insurgency in Nepal]]. The game follows Ajay Ghale, a young Kyrati-American who returns to his native country of Kyrat (a fictional [[Himalayas|Himalayan]] country derived from the [[Kirati people|Kirat]] ethnicities of Nepal and northern India) to spread his deceased mother's ashes. Kyrat was once an autonomous state in the Himalayas ruled by a royal family before being engulfed in a series of civil wars. Ajay finds the country in a state of conflict between Kyrat's Royal Army, led by the country's eccentric and tyrannical King Pagan Min, and the Golden Path, a rebel movement fighting to free Kyrat from Min's oppressive rule. The choices Ajay makes will determine the fate of Kyrat.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.gamespot.com/articles/far-cry-4-story-details-emerge/1100-6419756/|title=Far Cry 4 story details emerge|first=Chris|last=Pereira |date=May 20, 2014|accessdate=August 26, 2015|work=[[GameSpot]]}}</ref>
===Plot=== After the death of his mother Ishwari, Ajay Ghale ([[James A. Woods]]) returns to his home country of Kyrat to carry out Ishwari's final wish by returning her ashes to Lakshmana. However, his mission is interrupted when the bus he is traveling on is attacked by the Royal Army and he is taken prisoner by Pagan Min ([[Troy Baker]]), the country's eccentric and violent king, who claims to have been romantically involved with Ishwari. After finding his way through Pagan's mansion, Ajay escapes with the aid of Sabal ([[Naveen Andrews]]), a commander in the Golden Path, a rebel movement established by Ajay's father, Mohan Ghale. Ajay is not able to leave the country as the Royal Army has taken control of Kyrat's only airport and sealed the borders.
{{multiple image|caption_align=center|header_align=center | align = right | total_width = 300 | image1 = Troy baker taiyoucon 2011 cropped.jpg | alt1 = Photograph of Troy Baker | image2 = MyleneDinhRobic.WikiFr.jpg | alt2 = Photograph of Mylène Dinh-Robic | footer = Troy Baker and Mylène Dinh-Robic voice two of the game's antagonists}} In the twenty-odd years since Ishwari and Ajay fled Kyrat, the rebellion has stagnated, with the Golden Path now fighting for their very existence. As the son of Mohan Ghale, Ajay becomes a symbol for the Golden Path to rally around. After freeing a group of hostages and liberating territory held by Pagan, the Golden Path plan on breaking Pagan's stranglehold on power by targeting his three regional governors: Paul "De Pleur" Harmon ([[Travis Willingham]]), who oversees opium production and runs Pagan's torture chambers; Noore Najjar ([[Mylène Dinh-Robic]]), who runs poaching and prostitution rings and who became a victim of Pagan's cruelty herself after he kidnapped her family; and Yuma Lau ([[Gwendoline Yeo]]), Min's adopted sister and trusted general who is obsessed with uncovering the secrets of the mystical realm of Shangri-La.
However the Golden Path's newfound momentum is threatened by deep divisions between its commanders, Sabal, who favors traditional values, and Amita ([[Janina Gavankar]]), who argues for progress, which includes relying heavily on drug trade. Ajay is forced to intervene on several occasions, with his decisions influencing the direction the Golden Path takes. The first governor to fall is De Pleur after Noore helps Ajay find a way to infiltrate De Pleur's stronghold, allowing the rebellion to capture him. Amita and Sabal later task Ajay with confronting and killing Noore. She dies in her fighting arena, either with Ajay killing her, or with Noore committing suicide upon learning Pagan had her family executed years beforehand.
As the Golden Path secures Kyrat's southern provinces, Ajay is contacted by Willis Huntley ([[Alain Goulem]]), a CIA agent who offers intelligence for the rebels and pages from his father's diary in exchange for killing Yuma's lieutenants. After Ajay kills several of them, Huntley admits they were in fact CIA assets, and that he was sent to clean up after the CIA as the agency did not see Pagan as a threat anymore. Huntley betrays Ajay to Pagan just as the Golden Path prepare to push into Northern Kyrat.
Ajay ends up in Yuma's mountain prison, from which he manages to escape. In the process he finds out that Yuma has started despising Pagan, primarily because of his affections toward Ajay's late mother.{{efn|The ''Escape from Durgesh Prison'' downloadable content takes place at this point in the story.}} The Golden Path pushes into the north, and while Ajay attempts to reconnect with another faction of the rebels, Pagan, aware of Yuma's plotting against him, betrays Yuma to the Golden Path. Ajay is drawn into a confrontation with her and prevails, but tensions between Amita and Sabal reach new heights, and Ajay is forced to make a final decision as to who will lead the Golden Path. Whichever leader he chooses then sends Ajay to kill the other to prevent them from starting another civil war, and Ajay can choose to either kill them as ordered or let them go. With the Golden Path now united under a single leader, Ajay joins them for an attack on Pagan's fortress and pushes on alone to Pagan's palace while the Golden Path holds off the military.
====Endings==== Ajay encounters Pagan, who chastises him for fleeing at the start of the game, claiming that he only ever intended to help Ajay. Pagan offers Ajay a final decision: shoot him now, or listen to him. If Ajay shoots Pagan, the game ends immediately and the credits roll. If Ajay instead chooses to listen, Pagan reveals that Mohan sent Ishwari to spy on Pagan in the early days of the Golden Path, but they fell in love and had a daughter together: Lakshmana, Ajay's [[half-sister]]. Mohan killed Lakshmana for Ishwari's betrayal, and Ishwari killed him in turn before leaving the country with the infant Ajay. Pagan shows Ajay to a shrine containing Lakshmana's ashes, and Ajay places Ishwari's ashes inside. Pagan then boards a helicopter and departs peacefully, leaving the country in Ajay's hands. The player can choose to shoot down Pagan's helicopter as it flies away, killing Pagan in the process.
In the aftermath, the Golden Path seizes control of Kyrat. The final ending depends on which leader Ajay ultimately sided with. If Amita is placed in charge, she turns Kyrat into an [[authoritarian]] drug state, forcing villagers into work in factories and drug fields, and [[Conscription|conscripting]] [[Child soldiers|children]] into the group as soldiers to bolster their ranks against the remnants of the Royal Army; Ajay also learns that she has had her sister, Bhadra, taken away, "never to come again". If Sabal is placed in charge, Kyrat becomes a religious fundamentalist theocracy where all of Amita's supporters are executed, with Bhadra anointed as a religious symbol for the country to rally around. The player has the choice to kill the Golden Path's leader or leave them alive.
An [[Easter egg (media)|Easter egg]] ending can be found at the beginning of the game. To trigger it, Ajay must simply wait at the dinner table in Pagan's mansion; when Pagan returns, he thanks Ajay during the ensuing conversation for being a "gentleman", and leads him to Lakshmana's shrine, telling Ajay of his family history before he plants his mother's ashes at the shrine. After Ajay exits the shrine, Pagan invites Ajay to join him to "finally shoot some goddamn guns".<ref>Good, Owen. (November 15, 2014). [http://www.polygon.com/2014/11/15/7225121/far-cry-4-alternate-ending-video "How to finish Far Cry 4 in less than 30 minutes"]. ''[[Polygon (website)|Polygon]]''. Retrieved June 24, 2015.</ref>
===''Escape from Durgesh Prison''=== ''Escape from Durgesh Prison'' is an additional chapter of the story available as downloadable content. It expands upon Ajay's escape from the Durgesh prison and return to the Golden Path, and on Yuma's planned insurrection against Pagan Min.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://kotaku.com/far-cry-4s-dlc-forces-you-to-grind-until-you-die-for-no-1679524914|title=Far Cry 4's New DLC Forces You to Grind Until You Die For No Good Reason|first=Yannick|last=LeJacq|work=[[Kotaku]]|date=January 14, 2015|accessdate=November 3, 2015}}</ref>
Following Ajay's escape, he is left stranded in the snow at high altitude where he is rescued by Pagan Min. After tending to Ajay's wounds, Min leaves him in a tower in Northern Kyrat, as he is unable to return Ajay to the Golden Path directly. He then leaks news of Ajay's escape to Sabal and Amita, and allows them to secure a Royal Army helicopter so that they can extract him. However, word of this has spread to Yuma, who marshals the forces loyal to her and plans to attack the landing site once Ajay tries to escape. Because of this, Ajay only has a limited window of opportunity to escape, but can buy more time by attacking Yuma's forces. In exchange for disrupting Yuma's plans for a coup, Min promises Ajay support and resources at the landing site. During his missions, Ajay overhears one of the guards of Yuma saying that she was sent to a valley in the northern mountains of Kyrat on an expedition after something of great power called "The Relic". After killing Yuma's lieutenants, disrupting her supply lines, and thwarting her plans to sabotage Min's communications, Ajay ventures to the landing site where he is forced to fight off Yuma's attack long enough for the helicopter to power up. With the landing site secured and Yuma's forces in disarray, Ajay is successfully airlifted out contacts Sabal and Amita saying that he was heading to the valley to learn what is behind the expedition and the Relic.
===''Valley of the Yetis''=== ''Valley of the Yetis'' is a downloadable additional chapter of content which takes place directly after ''Escape from Durgesh Prison''.
In his way to the Lost Valley to learn more about the expedition Yuma sent after the Relic, Ajay's helicopter is shot down by an unknown assailant. Ajay survives the crash, but awakens to discover that the pilot has been abducted and taken deeper into the valley. Ajay follows him intent on rescue, only to discover that the valley is occupied by an aggressive army. Liberating a relay station in a bid to re-establish contact with the Golden Path, he is forced to fight off wave after wave of attackers whilst being taunted by a voice over the radio. Investigating further, Ajay discovers the army is calling themselves the Disciples of Yalung, and is a [[cult]] worshiping a demon from Kyrati mythology. The Disciples have harnessed an evil that permeates the valley to transform their followers into "Awakened", or [[yeti]]s, and are amassing their forces to attack Kyrat. Realizing that he cannot return to Kyrat without dealing with the cult, Ajay gradually destroys their ranks before scaling a glacier to find the source of Yalung's influence. After successfully destroying a tree that provides the Disciples with their power, Ajay sees himself as an Awakened, although this is supposedly just a hallucination.
==Development== The game's development was led by [[Ubisoft Montreal]], which took over the development of the ''Far Cry'' franchise after the release of ''[[Far Cry: Instincts]]'' in 2005. Additional development was handled by four other in-house Ubisoft studios, [[Ubisoft Toronto]], [[Red Storm Entertainment]], [[Ubisoft Shanghai]], and [[Ubisoft Kiev]].<ref>{{cite web|url=http://blog.ubi.com/far-cry-4-release-date-kyrat/|title=Far Cry 4 – Welcome To Kyrat|first= Gary |last=Steinman|publisher=[[Ubisoft]]|date=May 15, 2014|accessdate=August 25, 2015}}</ref> The Montreal studio worked on the game's campaign, the Toronto studio worked on the Shangri-La segments of the campaign, Red Storm handled the development of the competitive multiplayer, the Shanghai studio worked on the hunting missions, and the Kiev studio developed the game's PC version.<ref name="VentureBeat interview">{{cite web|url=https://venturebeat.com/2014/10/14/how-ubisoft-aims-to-dominate-shooter-open-worlds-with-far-cry-4-interview/2/|title=How Ubisoft aims to dominate open-world shooters with Far Cry 4 (interview)|first=Dean|last=Takahashi|work=[[VentureBeat]]|date=October 14, 2014|accessdate=August 25, 2015}}</ref> Development of the game began in late 2012, after the shipment of ''[[Assassin's Creed III]]''. The game's creative director is Alex Hutchinson, who had previously worked on [[Maxis]]'s ''[[Spore (2008 video game)|Spore]]'' as well as ''Assassin's Creed III''.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.gameinformer.com/b/features/archive/2014/06/25/history-lessons-the-road-from-assassins-creed-iii-to-far-cry-4.aspx|title=History Lessons: The Road From Assassin's Creed III To Far Cry 4|first=Ben|last=Hanson|work=[[Game Informer]]|date=June 25, 2014|accessdate=August 25, 2015}}</ref>
When brainstorming ideas for the new ''Far Cry'' game, the development team originally planned on developing a direct sequel to ''Far Cry 3.'' The sequel would be set on the same tropical island, would expand upon the protagonist's story, and would bring back characters, such as ''Far Cry 3''<nowiki/>'s secondary antagonist, Vaas. However, after four days, the team found that a sequel was not what they wanted to achieve. As a result, they decided to scrap the idea and build a brand new game with a new setting and a new set of characters. The team adapted a "we want it all" approach, in which they hoped to experiment with all kinds of ideas.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.vg247.com/2014/10/15/far-cry-4-pc-ps4-xbox-one/|title=Far Cry 3.5 was a thing – for about four days, says Ubisoft|first= Stephany|last= Nunneley|work=[[VG247]]|date=October 15, 2014|accessdate=August 25, 2015}}</ref> Some team members hoped that the game would allow players to fly, which led to the game's verticality.<ref name="FarCry3.5">{{cite web|url=http://blog.ubi.com/far-cry-4-isnt-just-far-cry-3-5/|title=Why Far Cry 4 Isn't Just Far Cry 3.5|first=Gary|last=Steinman|publisher=[[Ubisoft]]|date=October 14, 2014|accessdate=August 25, 2015}}</ref> The game's director also hoped that players would be able to ride a rampaging elephant, in a place with "exotic mountainsides" and "unique culture". This led to the concept of a mountainous setting and the introduction of elephants in the game.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.polygon.com/2014/10/14/6970783/i-played-far-cry-4-for-five-hours-and-heres-what-i-think-of-the-game|title=I played Far Cry 4 for five hours, and here's what I think of the game so far ...|first=Colin|last=Campbell|work=[[Polygon (website)|Polygon]]|date=October 14, 2014|accessdate=August 25, 2015}}</ref> The developers aimed for players to consider ''Far Cry 4'' a standalone experience, and therefore they avoided bringing back any characters from ''Far Cry 3'' except for Willis and Hurk{{who|date=March 2018}} The decision to bring the two back was made because the team thought that they should provide some references to previous games in the series, as all of the games are set in the same universe even though they are not directly related.<ref name="DSInterview">{{cite web|url=http://www.digitalspy.com/gaming/interviews/a592636/far-cry-4-interview-alex-hutchinson-on-kyrat-pagan-min-and-co-op.html#~pmnhi0dIkd5ao1|title=Far Cry 4 interview: Alex Hutchinson on Kyrat, Pagan Min and co-op|first=Matthew|last=Reynolds|work=[[Digital Spy]]|date=August 29, 2014|accessdate=August 25, 2015}}</ref>
Some of the gameplay elements were directly taken from ''Far Cry 3''. Exotic locations, hunting, and the freedom for players to complete missions through different approaches were maintained in ''Far Cry 4''. The team hoped that by incorporating and expanding upon on these ideas, while introducing new features, they could make ''Far Cry 4'' an evolution for the series. As a result, the size of the game's outposts became larger and players were given more options to customize their weapons.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.ign.com/articles/2014/08/08/far-cry-4-creative-director-discusses-the-returning-elements-of-far-cry-3|title=Far Cry 4 Creative Director Discusses The Returning Elements of Far Cry 3|first=Cassidee|last=Moser|work=[[IGN]]|date=August 8, 2014|accessdate=August 25, 2015}}</ref> The team also realized that players spent a lot of time interacting with the open world of ''Far Cry 3'', and decided to put more effort and resources into the world's design and add more quests to the game.<ref name="VentureBeat interview"/>
The game's setting, Kyrat, is a fictional country in the Himalayas region. When building Kyrat, the developers merged elements from real-world regions including [[Nepal]] and [[Tibet]], but exaggerated those elements. The map's size is similar to that of ''Far Cry 3'', but is more dense, diverse, and features more varied environments. The developers hoped that players could experience a sense of exploration when traveling between the different terrains.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.pcgamer.com/far-cry-4-interview-with-creative-director-alex-hutchinson-at-e3-2014/|title=Far Cry 4 interview with creative director Alex Hutchinson at E3 2014|work=[[PC Gamer]]|date=June 11, 2014|accessdate=August 25, 2015}}</ref> The team also hoped that the new location could be believable, while remaining interesting for players. As a result, they created an identity for Kyrat by doing such things as adding different signboards to the game and creating a fictional mythology and religion for Kyrat. The game's world was also designed to accommodate new features such as the helicopter and the grappling hook. In an effort to make the world feel real, the team added improvements to the design of side-quests. Instead of simply being activities for players to complete, the quests are narrative-driven, which was done to increase the connection between them and the world.<ref name="DSInterview"/> In order to increase the credibility of the game's world, the studio sent a team to Nepal to experience and record the local culture,<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.digitalspy.com/gaming/news/a589108/far-cry-4-behind-the-scenes-trailer-sees-developers-visit-a-hindu-temple.html#~prIxN5ZC6YXODx|title=Exclusive: Far Cry 4 behind-the-scenes trailer sees developers visit a Hindu temple|first=Matthew|last=Reynolds|work=[[Digital Spy]]|date=August 7, 2014|accessdate=October 21, 2015}}</ref> so that they could bring those ideas back to the studio. According to the developer, the trip changed the game's design; the focus shifted from the game's civil war, which is inspired by the real-world [[Nepalese Civil War]],<ref name="playstationlifestyle.net">{{cite web|url=http://www.playstationlifestyle.net/2014/08/24/far-cry-4-story-inspired-by-nepalese-civil-war/#/slide/1/|title=Far Cry 4 Inspired by Nepalese Civil War According to Ubisoft|last=Khan|first=Zarmena|work=[[PlayStation LifeStyle]]|date=August 24, 2014|accessdate=August 25, 2014}}</ref> to developing unique and interesting characters.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.gameinformer.com/games/far_cry_4/b/playstation4/archive/2014/06/18/to-nepal-and-back-how-ubisoft-montreal-created-a-new-country-for-far-cry-4.aspx|title=Far Cry 4: To Nepal And Back: How Ubisoft Montreal Created A New Country|first=Ben|last=Reeves|work=[[Game Informer]]|date=June 18, 2014|accessdate=August 25, 2015}}</ref>
One of the game's most critically acclaimed characters is Pagan Min, the game's major antagonist. The team hoped that players would be "shocked, amazed and intrigued" by him in every encounter. Min has a complex relationship with the playable character, Ghale, as the team wanted players to guess Min's intentions and add a layer of mystery to him.<ref name="VentureBeat interview"/> The team originally hoped to have a villain that had a "punk-rock mentality", but the idea was abandoned as the team thought that the concept was not original. The pink costume Min wears throughout the game was inspired by Beat Takeshi, a character from ''[[Brother (2000 film)|Brothers]]'', and Ichi, a character from ''[[Ichi the Killer (film)|Ichi the Killer]]''. Min is designed to be sadistic yet confident, and the team hired [[Troy Baker]] to provide the voice for Min, as they thought that Baker's voice is charismatic enough to suit Min.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.gameinformer.com/games/far_cry_4/b/xboxone/archive/2014/06/13/the-face-of-evil-a-look-at-far-cry-4-controversial-villain.aspx|title=Far Cry 4: The Face Of Evil: A Look At Ubisoft's Controversial Villain|first=Ben|last=Reeves|work=[[Game Informer]]|date=June 13, 2014|accessdate=August 25, 2015}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.gamespot.com/articles/exploring-far-cry-4s-sadistic-complicated-villain-/1100-6422572/|title=Exploring Far Cry 4's Sadistic, Complicated Villain Pagan Min|first=Justin|last=Haywald|date=September 26, 2014|accessdate=August 25, 2015|work=[[GameSpot]]}}</ref> According to Baker, Ubisoft gave him a script for the audition but he chose not to follow it, and instead decided to threaten to cut off the face of an assistant using Min's tone. The interviewer was very pleased with Baker's performance and decided to sign him for the job.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.gamespot.com/articles/far-cry-4s-crazy-pagan-min-audition-involved-threa/1100-6428614/|title=Far Cry 4's Crazy Pagan Min Audition Involved Threat of Cutting Someone's Face Off|first=Chris|last=Pereira|date=July 2, 2015|accessdate=August 25, 2015}}</ref> As for Ghale, he was designed to be "thin", and his backstory was designed to be revealed as players progressed through the game's story.<ref name="FarCry3.5"/> According to the game's narrative director, Mark Thompson, Ghale learns the history and culture of Kyrat along with players. The developers also hoped that Ghale could be an accessible character for players.<ref name="GI"/>
{{quote box|quote=We decided to shift away from a main character and no longer treat the player like he’s just along for the ride. We shifted to the story of the player and the story the player wants to explore.|width=33%|source= —Lucien Soulban, lead writer of ''Far Cry 4''<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.vg1247.com/2014/10/21/far-cry-4-same-day-different-story/|title=Far Cry 4: same day, different story|first=Patrick|last=Garratt|work=[[VG247]]|date=October 21, 2014|accessdate=August 26, 2015|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20151208070819/http://www.vg1247.com/2014/10/21/far-cry-4-same-day-different-story/|archivedate=December 8, 2015|df=mdy-all}}</ref>}}
In hindsight, the team considered the story of ''Far Cry 3'' "great", even though they thought that it was separated from the game's world. In order to increase players' agency and make the story to feel more connected to the world for players, the team introduced a branching storyline which required players to make choices that would lead to different results and alter the game's ending.<ref name="PolyE3">{{cite web|url=http://www.polygon.com/a/e3-2014/far-cry-4|title=Far Cry's new creative director talks story, co-op and scope|first=Alexa|last=Ray Corriea|work=[[Polygon (website)|Polygon]]|accessdate=August 25, 2015}}</ref> The team hoped that by adding choices, they could add additional depth and meaning to the game's campaign. Thompson added that they twisted the story of ''Far Cry 3'' for ''Far Cry 4'', and made outsiders the villains instead of the heroes. The team considered it a "risk", but they wanted to try something different.<ref name="GINarrative">{{cite web|url=http://www.gameinformer.com/b/features/archive/2014/06/16/far-cry-4s-new-approach-to-narrative.aspx|title=Embracing Chaos: Far Cry 4's New Approach To Narrative|first=Ben|last=Hanson|work=[[Game Informer]]|date=June 16, 2014|accessdate=August 25, 2015}}</ref>
[[File:Far Cry 4 Shangri-La screenshot.jpg|thumb|left|The Shangri-La section features a color scheme that is different from Kyrat. It is mostly made up of gold, red, orange, white and blue.]] For the Shangri-La mission, the team wanted to have a structure similar to ''3'''s mushroom missions; a game within a game.<ref name="FarCry3.5"/> The Shangri-La missions are not related to Kyrat, but play an important role in the game's narrative. When creating these segments, the team put a lot of emphasis on the use of colors. They hoped that the artistic vision for ''Far Cry 4'' would not feature any resemblance to other typical shooter games. It was originally designed to be a small open world, but was later converted into a linear experience due to time constraints and huge creative differences between developers. The team later decided to simplify it, and re-imagined it into an "ancient, natural world". It is made up of five different colors. The main color of Shangri-La is gold; the developers thought that using gold as the foundation added "warmth" to the dreamland. Meanwhile, red was used heavily to add a sense of strangeness, as well as for establishing a tie to the game's narrative and story. Orange was used as a color of interaction, while white was used to add purity to the world. Blue is the last of Shangri-La's main colors, and represents dangers and honor.<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.polygon.com/features/2015/3/16/8219481/shangri-la-far-cry-4-artwork-gallery-gdc-2015|title=Painting Shangri-La|first=Dave|last=Tach|work=[[Polygon (website)|Polygon]]|date=March 16, 2015|accessdate=August 25, 2015}}</ref>
Ubisoft promised that ''Far Cry 4'' would have much more of a multiplayer element than ''Far Cry 3''.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.gamespot.com/articles/far-cry-4-will-have-a-lot-more-multiplayer-than-far-cry-3/1100-6419681/|title=Far Cry 4 will have "a lot more multiplayer" than Far Cry 3|first=Eddie|last=Makuch|work=[[GameSpot]]|date=May 16, 2014|accessdate=August 26, 2015}}</ref> Some elements that were scrapped for ''Far Cry 3'' due to time constraints were featured in ''Far Cry 4'', such as the "Guns for Hire" co-operative multiplayer mode.<ref name="VentureBeat interview"/> Building a co-operative experience was the team's goal starting from the beginning of the game's development. Originally intended to be a separate mode, it was later made to be seamlessly integrated into the main campaign.<ref name="PolyE3"/> The game's competitive multiplayer was designed to give players freedom, allowing players to progress and defeat enemies through a variety of different ways. Red Storm Entertainment also considered players' feedback from the multiplayer aspect of ''Far Cry 3'', and decided to include vehicles to the game. The company chose an asymmetrical structure for the match, so that players could have different experiences in different matches, as well as to make matches feel more chaotic.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.gametrailers.com/videos/iukn6b/far-cry-4-the-making-of-pvp--battles-of-kyrat-|title=Far Cry 4:The Making of PvP (Battles of Kyrat)|work=[[GameTrailers]]|date=December 4, 2014|accessdate=August 25, 2015}}</ref> The developers originally planned to feature female playable characters, but the plan was scrapped due to animation problems.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.eurogamer.net/articles/2014-06-12-far-cry-4-almost-had-female-co-op-characters|title=Far Cry 4 "almost" had female co-op characters|first=Tom|last=Phillips|work=[[Eurogamer]]|date=June 12, 2014|accessdate=August 26, 2015}}</ref> Ubisoft announced a 'Keys to Kyrat' offer for players that owned a copy of the game for the PlayStation 3 or PlayStation 4. It allows those owners to send out game keys to up to ten other people who do not own a copy of the game. Players who are offered a key can join the person that sent them the key and play the co-operative mode for two hours.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.psu.com/News/24977/Far-Cry-4-PlayStation-exclusive-Keys-to-Kyrat-offer-unlimited-sessions|title=Far Cry 4 PlayStation exclusive 'Keys to Kyrat' offer 'unlimited sessions'|first=Simon|last=Sayers|work=[[PlayStation Universe]]|date=October 20, 2014|accessdate=August 26, 2015}}</ref>
[[Cliff Martinez]] was hired to work on the game's soundtrack. A two disc edition was released that contained 30 tracks heard in the game, and a deluxe edition was released that contained 15 extra tracks. The album was released just before the release of the game, and received positive reviews. Particular praise was directed towards the usage of traditional Nepalese instruments which, combined with electronic samples, suggested high octane action and mystical wondering.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.ign.com/articles/2014/11/03/composer-cliff-martinez-officially-working-on-far-cry-4-soundtrack|title=Composer Cliff Martinez Officially Working On Far Cry 4 Soundtrack|first=Lauren|last=Puga|work=[[IGN]]|date=November 3, 2014|accessdate=August 26, 2015}}</ref>
===Release=== With ''Far Cry 3'' being a commercial success, Ubisoft considered the ''Far Cry'' series one of their most important brands, and they hinted that a sequel was in development in June 2013.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.ign.com/articles/2013/06/20/ubisoft-more-far-cry-games-are-coming|title=Ubisoft: More Far Cry Games Are Coming|first=Andrew|last=Goldfarb|date=June 20, 2013|accessdate=August 26, 2015|work=[[IGN]]}}</ref> On October 3, 2013, Martinez mentioned that he was working on the soundtrack for the game.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.engadget.com/2013/10/08/drive-composer-cliff-martinez-mentions-work-on-far-cry-4/|title='Drive' composer Cliff Martinez mentions work on Far Cry 4|first=Mike|last=Suszek|work=[[Joystiq]]|date=October 8, 2013|accessdate=August 26, 2015}}</ref> In March 2014 the game's setting and features were leaked.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.eurogamer.net/articles/2014-03-20-far-cry-4-set-in-the-himalayas-has-ridable-elephants|title=Far Cry 4 set in the Himalayas, has ridable elephants|first=Tom|last=Phillips|work=[[Eurogamer]]|date=March 21, 2014|accessdate=August 26, 2015}}</ref> The game was officially announced on May 15, 2014, and the first gameplay footage was revealed during [[Electronic Entertainment Expo 2014]].<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.ign.com/articles/2014/05/15/far-cry-4-announced-for-2014|title=Far Cry 4 Announced for 2015|first=Mitch|last=Dyer|work=[[IGN]]|date=May 15, 2015|accessdate=August 26, 2015}}</ref> The game's cover art, which shows the light-skinned Pagan Min resting his hand on a dark-skinned person, caused controversy and accusation of racism. Hutchinson later responded and clarified by saying that Pagan Min is not a white person, and that the other person depicted is not the game's protagonist.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.ign.com/articles/2014/05/21/far-cry-4-creative-director-addresses-box-art-controversy|title=Far Cry 4 Creative Director Addresses Box Art Controversy|first=Lucy|last=O'Brien|work=[[IGN]]|date=May 20, 2014|accessdate=August 26, 2015}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.gamespot.com/articles/far-cry-4-creative-director-comments-on-controversial-box-art/1100-6419759/|title=Far Cry 4 creative director comments on controversial box art|first=Chris|last=Pereira|date=May 20, 2014|accessdate=August 26, 2015|work=[[GameSpot]]}}</ref> Hutchinson added that the reaction of the community regarding the cover art was "uncomfortable".<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.eurogamer.net/articles/2014-06-23-dont-judge-far-cry-4-by-its-cover-says-game-director?|title=Don't judge Far Cry 4 by its cover, says game director|first=Jeffery|last=Matulef|work=[[Eurogamer]]|date=June 24, 2014|accessdate=August 26, 2015}}</ref>
In addition to the standard version, a ''Limited Edition'' of the game could be purchased. This edition features additional in-game missions and an Impaler Harpoon Gun. The Limited Edition was a free upgrade for players who pre-ordered the game.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.engadget.com/2014/10/03/far-cry-4-limited-edition-adds-extra-missions-bonus-monkeys/|title=Far Cry 4 Limited Edition adds extra missions, bonus monkeys|first=Danny|last=Cowan|work=[[Joystiq]]|date=October 3, 2014|accessdate=August 26, 2015}}</ref> A ''Kyrat Edition'' was also announced and it contains a collector's box, a poster, a journal, a map of Kyrat, a figurine of Pagan Min, and the missions from the Limited Edition.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.gameinformer.com/games/far_cry_4/b/playstation4/archive/2014/07/06/far-cry-4-kyrat-edition-includes-pagan-min-statue.aspx|title=Far Cry 4 Kyrat Edition Includes Pagan Min Statue|first=Kyle|last=Hilliard|work=[[Game Informer]]|date=July 6, 2014|accessdate=August 26, 2015}}</ref> Players can also purchase a season pass for the game, which grants them access to additional content, including a new competitive multiplayer mode, a mission called "the Syringe", the missions from the ''Limited Edition'', and the two other pieces of downloadable content.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.gamespot.com/articles/30-far-cry-4-season-pass-announced-includes-multip/1100-6423065/|title=$30 Far Cry 4 Season Pass Announced, Includes Multiplayer Mode and Yeti Missions|first=Eddie|last=Makuch|work=[[GameSpot]]|date=October 20, 2014|accessdate=August 26, 2015}}</ref> ''Far Cry 4: Arena Master'', developed by Ludomade, was released alongside the game itself, as a companion app for the [[iOS]] and [[Android (operating system)|Android]].<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.engadget.com/2014/11/22/far-cry-4-arcade-poker-arena-master-apps-now-in-the-wild/|title=Far Cry 4 Arcade Poker, Arena Master apps now in the wild|first=Thomas |last=Schulenberg|work=[[Engadget]]|date=November 22, 2014|accessdate=April 15, 2018}}</ref>
''Far Cry 4'' was released worldwide on November 18, 2014 for [[Microsoft Windows]], [[PlayStation 3]], [[PlayStation 4]], [[Xbox 360]] and [[Xbox One]].<ref>{{cite web|url=http://ign.com/articles/2014/11/03/composer-cliff-martinez-officially-working-on-far-cry-4-soundtrack|title=Composer Cliff Martinez Officially Working on Far Cry 4 Soundtrack|first=Lauren|last=Puga|work=[[IGN]]|date=November 3, 2014|accessdate=December 23, 2017}}</ref> The PlayStation 4, Xbox One and PC versions feature higher visual fidelity, such as having a higher texture resolution and more animal fur.<ref name="DSInterview" /> The game was supported by downloadable content upon launch. The first DLC, ''Escape From Durgesh Prison'', featuring a new mission set during the main campaign, was released on January 13, 2015. It can be played solo or with another player.<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.vg247.com/2015/01/13/far-cry-4s-escape-from-durgesh-prison-dlc-is-now-available/|title=Far Cry 4’s Escape from Durgesh Prison DLC is now available|first=Sherif|last=Saed|work=[[VG247]]|date=January 13, 2015|accessdate=August 26, 2015}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.gamespot.com/articles/far-cry-4-permadeth-dlc-available-now/1100-6424617/|title=Far Cry 4 Permadeth DLC Available Now|first=Eddie|last=Makuch|work=[[GameSpot]]|date=January 13, 2015|accessdate=August 26, 2015}}</ref> The ''Overrun'' DLC, which added new maps, a new vehicle, and a new mode to the game's competitive multiplayer, was released on February 10, 2015 for the consoles, and February 12, 2015 for PC.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.ign.com/articles/2015/02/10/far-cry-4-overrun-dlc-out-now|title=Far Cry 4 Overrun DLC Out Now|first=Michael|last=Martin|work=[[IGN]]|date=February 10, 2015|accessdate=August 26, 2015}}</ref> The ''Hurk Deluxe Pack'' was released on January 28, 2015 and added several story missions and weapons.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.vg247.com/2015/01/28/far-cry-4-hurk-deluxe-dlc-now-available/|title=Far Cry 4 Hurk Deluxe DLC now available|first=Brenna|last=Hillier|work=[[VG247]]|date=January 28, 2015|accessdate=August 26, 2015}}</ref> The last downloadable content, ''Valley of the Yetis'', features a new region and new story missions which can be played solo or co-cooperatively with another player. ''Valley of the Yetis'' was released on March 10, 2015 in North America and March 11, 2015 in Europe.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.gamesradar.com/far-cry-4-dlc/|title=Far Cry 4 Valley of the Yetis DLC hits in March|work=[[GamesRadar]]|date=February 28, 2015|accessdate=August 26, 2015}}</ref>

''Far Cry 4'' received a positive reception upon release. Aggregating review websites [[GameRankings]] and [[Metacritic]] gave the Xbox One version 85.92% based on 12 reviews and 82/100 based on 14 reviews, respectively.<ref name="GRXONE"/><ref name="MCXONE"/> The PlayStation 4 version received 83.76% based on 57 reviews on GameRankings and 85/100 based on 83 reviews on Metacritic,<ref name="GRPS4"/><ref name="MCPS4"/> and the Microsoft Windows version received 81.00% based on 9 reviews and 80/100 based on 17 reviews, respectively.<ref name="GRPC"/><ref name="MCPC"/>
The game's story received mixed responses. Chris Carter from [[Destructoid]] praised the personality of Ajay Ghale, which is "less in-your-face" than that of ''Far Cry 3'''s protagonist [[Jason Brody]]. He also praised the villain, Pagan Min, who he considered took the spotlight every time he appeared in the game.<ref name="Destruct"/> Josh Harmon from ''[[Electronic Gaming Monthly]]'' thought that the characters in this game had more depth, and that the choices made by players throughout the game were meaningful.<ref name="EGM"/> Aoife Wilson from [[Eurogamer]] thought that the game's characters were memorable, but was disappointed by the story.<ref name="EuroG"/> Nick Tan, from [[Game Revolution]], also praised Min's personality, but he complained that the character appeared too seldom in the game.<ref name="GameRev"/> Edwin Evans-Thirlwell, writing for [[GamesRadar]], thought that the story grew tiresome as players progressed, even though some of its characters were interesting. He further criticized the game's writing, which he thought was lackluster.<ref name="GRadar"/> Mike Splechta from ''GameZone'' praised the game's voice acting and applauded its storyline, calling it satisfying.<ref name="GZ"/>
The game's setting received positive responses. Carter thought that the verticality nature of the game's map created obstacles for players when they were traveling between places. However, he praised the interesting lore and wildlife found within the world, as well as the game's long [[draw distance]].<ref name="Destruct"/> Harmon had similar comments, praising the game's graphics and Kyrat's culture. Harmon thought that the hilly landscape of the game's world gave players a sense of exploration, and hence made traversal enjoyable.<ref name="EGM"/> Wilson thought, however, that the game's setting was not as compelling as the tropical setting of ''Far Cry 3''.<ref name="EuroG"/> Nevertheless, she praised the Shangri-la section, which she thought had changed the game's landscape drastically. Matt Bertz from ''[[Game Informer]]'' praised the game's setting, which he thought was vibrant, varied and rich.<ref name="GI"/> Ludwig Kietzmann from [[Joystiq]] praised the content found within the world, and thought that the world itself was absorbing and interesting.<ref name="Joystiq2"/>
The game's design also received acclaim. Carter from Destructoid thought that the fortress and the outpost system provided players with a sense of accomplishment and success, and he considered having the freedom to use different ways to approach and complete missions one of the greatest parts of the game. In addition, Carter applauded the game's driving mechanics and the auto-drive feature, which he considered a significant improvement for the series.<ref name="Destruct"/> However he criticized the upgrade system, which he thought was directly converted from ''Far Cry 3'' and was uninspiring. ''Electronic Gaming Monthly''<nowiki/>'s Harmon thought that the introduction of the helicopter was dull. Mitch Dyer, from [[IGN]], praised the game's economy system, which he thought was satisfying. He added that it gives players motivations to complete side-quests.<ref name="IGN"/> [[Justin McElroy]] of ''[[Polygon (website)|Polygon]]'' praised the introduction of the grappling hook and the vertical map-design, which he thought had allowed players to develop strategy before taking action. He also praised the game for allowing players to use multiple approaches towards a single objective.<ref name="Poly"/>
The game's multiplayer mode received mixed response. Carter compared the competitive multiplayer to that of ''[[Tomb Raider (2013 video game)|Tomb Raider]]'', and called it "skippable". He considered the co-operative multiplayer a fun addition to the game, but was disappointed by its limitations. He also added that the game would still be a strong title without these multiplayer elements.<ref name="Destruct"/> Bertz from ''Game Informer'' also found the multiplayer shallow and poorly-executed. He also criticized the lack of a large player pool and dedicated servers.<ref name="GI"/> Evans-Thirlwell of GamesRadar thought that the game's co-operative multiplayer were fun to play, but the asymmetrical competitive multiplayer was easy to forget.<ref name="GRadar"/> In contrast, ''GameZone''{{'s}} Splechta thought that the competitive multiplayer mode was "a surprise" for him.<ref name="GZ"/> Dyer echoed similar statement, and he thought that it had successfully captured the scale and freedom offered by both the game's co-op and campaign.<ref name="IGN"/>
Harmon thought that ''Far Cry 4'' was an improvement over ''Far Cry 3'', but he thought that the game felt and played too similarly to ''Far Cry 3'', and he added that the game was unambitious. Bertz thought that Ubisoft Montreal's vision for ''Far Cry 4'' is not as bold as its predecessors, and also thought that the experience delivered by ''Far Cry 4'' did not stray far away from ''Far Cry 3''.<ref name="GI"/> Tan also noted that the game's open world design felt not only similar to ''Far Cry 3'', but also other Ubisoft franchises like ''[[Assassin's Creed]]'' and ''[[Watch Dogs]]''.<ref name="GameRev"/> Evans-Thirlwell thought that the experience offered by ''Far Cry 4'' was hollow as it had failed to innovate or reinvent its wheel.<ref name="GRadar"/> Dyer thought that the game was not ambitious, but the experience delivered was still gratifying and rewarding.<ref name="IGN"/>

===Awards=== The game received the Best Shooter Award from [[IGN]].<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.ign.com/lists/best-of-games-genre/shooter|title=Best Games, By Genre|work=[[IGN]]|accessdate=August 26, 2015}}</ref> The game was nominated for Best Artistic Achievement, Best Game Design, Best Music, Best Performer (Troy Baker), and Best Story at the [[11th British Academy Games Awards]]. Awards Nominees Announced|first=Kevin|last=Dunsmore|work=[[Hardcore Gamer]]|date=January 15, 2015|accessdate=August 26, 2015}}</ref> At the [[11th British Academy Games Awards|BAFTA Game Awards]], Far Cry 4 received five nominations including best game design and best story eventually winning for best music.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://awards.bafta.org/award/2015/games|title=Games in 2015|work=[[BAFTA Games Awards|BAFTA Game Awards]]|accessdate=November 30, 2016}}</ref> The game won ''Game of the Year'' and ''Art Direction, Contemporary'' (Jean-Alexis Doyon) in 2014 by [[National Academy of Video Game Trade Reviewers]] (NAVGTR) and received six nominations: ''Use of Sound, Franchise'' (Yassine Abouelfalah), ''Sound Editing in a Game Cinema'' (Ding Jun Mei), ''Graphics, Technical'' (Danny Deslongchamps), ''Game, Franchise Action'' (Cedric Decelle), ''Game Design, Franchise'' (Gauthier Malou) and ''Direction in a Game Cinema'' (Sébastien Bergeron).<ref>{{cite web|title=NAVGTR Awards (2014)|url=http://navgtr.org/archives/2445|website=National Academy of Video Game Trade Reviewers}}</ref>

'''First-year composition''' (sometimes known as '''freshman composition''' or '''freshman writing''') is an introductory core curriculum [[writing]] course in American colleges. This course focuses on improving students' abilities to write in a university setting and introduces students to writing practices in the disciplines and professions.<ref>Duffy, John. "[http://www.insidehighered.com/views/2012/03/16/essay-value-first-year-writing-courses| Essay on the Value of First-year Writing Courses]." ''[[Inside Higher Ed]]''. March 16, 2012.</ref> These courses are traditionally required of incoming students, thus the previous name, "Freshman Composition". Scholars working within the field of Composition-Rhetoric often have teaching First-year composition (FYC) courses as the practical focus of their scholarly work.
FYC courses are structured in a variety of ways. Some institutions of higher education require only one term of FYC, while others require two or three courses. There are a number of identifiable [[Pedagogy|pedagogies]] associated with FYC, including: [[formalist theory in composition studies|current-traditional]], [[theories of rhetoric and composition pedagogy|expressivist]], [[Cognitive rhetoric|social-epistemic]], [[Process theory of composition|process]], post-process and [[Writing about Writing]] (WAW). Each of these [[pedagogy|pedagogies]] can generate a multitude of curricula.
Composition professionals, including those with degrees in Writing Studies and [[Rhetoric]] and [[Composition Studies|Composition]], often focus on a rhetorical approach to help students learn how to apply an understanding of [[audience]], purpose, [[Context (language use)|context]], invention, and [[Stylistics (literature)|style]] to their writing processes. This rhetorical approach has shown that real writing, rather than existing as isolated modes, has more to do with a writer choosing from among many approaches to perform rhetorical tasks.{{Citation needed|date=January 2018}} In addition to a focus on rhetoric, many first year composition courses also emphasize writing process, where students are encouraged to interact with classmates and receive feedback to be used for [[revision (writing) | revision]]. These practices can take the form of essay [[peer review]] or workshopping. [[Electronic Portfolio|Portfolios]] are a common way of assessing revised student work.<ref>"[http://www.ncte.org/cccc/resources/positions/electronicportfolios| Principles and Practices in Electronic Portfolios]." Conference on College Composition and Communication, 2007.</ref>
==History==
Since the late nineteenth century, college courses on composition have become increasingly common in American higher education.<ref>Crowley, Sharon. ''Composition in the University: Historical and Polemical Essays''. Pittsburgh, University of Pittsburgh Press: 1998.</ref> Although a longstanding course offering at many colleges, first-year composition remains controversial and marginalized.<ref>Miller, Susan. ''Textual Carnivals: The Politics of Composition.'' Carbondale and Edwardsville, IL: Southern Illinois University Press, 1991. </ref><ref>Holbrook, Sue Ellen. "Women's Work: The Feminizing of Composition." ''Rhetoric Review'' 9(2) 1991: 201-229. </ref>
===First-year requirement debate===
The requirement for a first-year composition course has been debated in [[composition studies]]. This debate centers around how effective the first-year composition course is and the changes that need to be made to develop the field of composition. While most schools do require some form of the first-year composition course, there are some schools that have decided to abolish the first-year composition requirement. Some scholars, such as Sharon Crowley in ''Composition in the University: Historical and Polemical Essays,'' argue that this requirement should be abolished. Crowley does not suggest the course itself be removed, only the requirement that all freshmen take the course. She states that students would still be interested in the course if the requirement was abolished and that removing the requirement would strengthen the field of composition. She implies that composition studies is marginalized within the university because of the view of the first-year composition course as a skill course. Removing the requirement, she states, would remove the association of composition studies with introductory courses, giving more acknowledgement to the field. <ref> Crowley, Sharon. ''Composition in the University: Historical and Polemical Essays''. Pittsburgh: University of Pittsburgh Press, 1998. pg 241-43. Print. </ref> Crowley's opinion initiated a debate in the composition field, but she is not the only critic who advocates for the removal of this requirement. Scholars Douglas Downs and Elizabeth Wardle also dislike the requirement and instead argue for a writing studies curriculum. <ref> Downs, Douglas and Elizabeth Wardle. ''Teaching About Writing, Righting Misconceptions: (Re)Envisioning 'First-Year Composition' as 'Introduction to Writing Studies'''. College Composition and Communication. 58.4 (2007) 552-584. Web. </ref> However, there are scholars who do not agree with this stance, argue that the first-year composition course is needed in the university, and believe that the requirement should remain. Scholar David Smit is one critic who favors keeping the requirement. He suggests that the requirement can be kept and the curriculum and structure of the first-year composition course altered for improvement. Smit explains that many of the developmental goals of those who favor abolishing the requirement can still be achieved by offering more writing experiences. He proposes more genre writing in composition courses with a "[[scaffolding]]" progression of discipline writing. If this was done, he suggests, the concerns over the status of composition studies in the university would still be solved, as the course would no longer be seen as skills based. <ref> Smit, David. ''The End of Composition Studies''. Carbondale: Southern Illinois University Press, 2004. pg 183-85. Print. </ref> There has been no consensus reached in composition studies regarding the status of the first-year composition course requirement. The benefits of the course, as well as the drawbacks, continue to be debated and the scholars noted above are only a few of the voices and perspectives involved in this discussion. Despite the debate about the requirement, it remains in effect at a majority of universities{{Citation needed|date=January 2018}}.
==Structure of contemporary first-year composition==
First-year composition is designed to meet the goals for successful completion set forth by the [http://wpacouncil.org/positions/outcomes.html/ Council of Writing Program Administrators]. To reach these goals, students must learn rhetorical conventions, [[critical thinking]] skills, [[information literacy]], and the process of writing an academic paper. While there is no American standard curriculum for first-year composition, curriculum is developed at several levels, including the state, institution, department, and [[Writing center|writing program]].
=== First-year composition and rhetoric ===
With the publication of James Kinneavy's ''Theory of Discourse'' in 1971, English departments began incorporating [[rhetoric]] into their composition classrooms.<ref>Clark, Irene. ''Concepts in Composition: Theory and Practice in the Teaching of Writing.'' Mahweh, NJ: Lawrence Erlbaum Associates, 2003. p 6.</ref> In doing this, composition instructors have placed more emphasis on teaching [[audience analysis]], [[Aristotle]]'s three appeals ([[ethos]], [[pathos]], and [[logos]]), and teaching Kinneavy's modes of discourse. According to Brian Sutton in "Writing in the Disciplines, First-Year Composition, and the Research Paper," since 1980, there has been an increasing debate in academic circles as to whether the "generic" approach to writing in first year composition is useful for students whose future writing will be discipline specific (46).<ref>Sutton, Brian. "Writing in the Disciplines, First-Year Composition, and the Research Paper." ''Language and Learning Across the Disciplines'' 2.1 (1997) 46–57. Web.</ref>
===Basic writing===
First described by [[Mina P. Shaughnessy|Mina Shaughnessy]] in the 1970s, [[Basic writing]] is a division of composition studies that strives to bring disadvantaged students entering college to a more complete understanding of the rhetorical aspects of the writing process.<ref>Otte, George, and Rebecca Mlynarczyk. "[http://www.ncte.org/college/briefs/basic|Issue Brief: Basic Writing]." National Council of Teachers of English. 2009.</ref>
== References == <references /> *Perryman-Clark, Staci. "Writing, Rhetoric and American Cultures (WRA) 125 – Writing: the Ethnic and Racial Experience." ''Composition Studies'' 37.2 (Fall 2009): 115–134.

'''Francis Morrone''' (born 12 May 1958) is an American [[architectural historian]] of mixed Irish and Italian heritage, originally from Chicago, known for his work on the built history of [[New York City]].<ref>[http://mas.org/tours/guides MAS Tour Leader Bios]</ref>
Morrone's essays on architecture have appeared in the ''[[Wall Street Journal]]'', ''[[City Journal (New York)|City Journal]]'', ''[[American Arts Quarterly]]'', the ''[[New Criterion]]'', ''[[Humanities]]'', and the ''[[New York Times]]''. He was a columnist for the ''[[New York Sun]]'' for six and a half years (2002-2008).<ref>[http://www.nysun.com/authors/Francis+Morrone Francis Morrone], New York Sun Archive.</ref> In April 2011, he was named by [[Travel + Leisure]] magazine as one of the 13 best [[tour guide]]s in the world.<ref>[http://www.travelandleisure.com/articles/worlds-greatest-tour-guides World's Greatest Tour Guides].</ref> Morrone was a 2012 recipient of the Arthur Ross Award of the Institute of Classical Architecture and Art,<ref>[http://www.classicist.org/awards-and-prizes/arthur-ross-awards/2012-ara 2012 Arthur Ross Awards]</ref> and a 2016 recipient of the Landmarks Lion Award of the [[Historic Districts Council]].<ref>[http://hdc.org/featured/lion2016 2016 Landmarks Lion Award]</ref> He also teaches at NYU and is an authority on Edith Wharton. He is married to Patricia Rainsford and lives in Park Slope, Brooklyn.
==Books== * ''[https://www.amazon.com/Guide-York-City-Urban-Landscapes/dp/0393733572/ref=sr_1_1?ie=UTF8&qid=1399576777&sr=8-1&keywords=guide+to+new+york+city+urban Guide to New York City Urban Landscapes]'' * ''[https://www.amazon.com/dp/1586850474 An Architectural Guidebook to Brooklyn]'' * ''[https://www.amazon.com/Architectural-Guidebook-New-York-City/dp/1586852116/ref=sr_1_3?s=books&ie=UTF8&qid=1346465692&sr=1-3&keywords=francis+morrone The Architectural Guidebook to New York City]'' * ''[https://www.amazon.com/Architectural-Guidebook-Philadelphia-Francis-Morrone/dp/B000H2MBGC/ref=sr_1_10?s=books&ie=UTF8&qid=1346465692&sr=1-10&keywords=francis+morrone An Architectural Guidebook to Philadelphia]'' * ''[https://www.amazon.com/Brooklyn-Journey-Through-City-Dreams/dp/0789310686/ref=sr_1_11?s=books&ie=UTF8&qid=1346465692&sr=1-11&keywords=francis+morrone Brooklyn: A Journey through the City of Dreams]'' * ''[http://books.wwnorton.com/books/detail.aspx?ID=4482 The Municipal Art Society of New York: 10 Architectural Walks in Manhattan]'' * ''[https://www.amazon.com/Memories-Times-Past-New-York/dp/B005K5SQ6U/ref=sr_1_7?s=books&ie=UTF8&qid=1346465692&sr=1-7&keywords=francis+morrone New York: Memories of Times Past]'' * ''[https://www.amazon.com/New-York-Public-Library-Architecture/dp/0393078108/ref=sr_1_1?s=books&ie=UTF8&qid=1346465692&sr=1-1&keywords=francis+morrone The New York Public Library: The Architecture and Decoration of the Stephen A. Schwarzman Building]'' * ''[http://brooklynhistory.org/publications/park_slope.html The Park Slope Neighborhood and Architectural History Guide]'' * ''[http://www.brooklynhistory.org/publications/guides/ftgreene_pop1.html The Fort Greene/Clinton Hill Neighborhood and Architectural History Guide]'' * ''[https://www.amazon.com/York-City-Landmarks-Francis-Morrone/dp/1851496696/ref=sr_1_8?ie=UTF8&qid=1399576996&sr=8-8&keywords=francis+morrone New York City Landmarks]''

{{for|the Bahamian basketball player|Buddy Hield}} {{use British English|date=October 2016}} {{Use dmy dates|date=June 2016}} {{Infobox company | logo = Hield logo on white - Small.jpg | name = Hield Bros. | type = [[Limited company|Private]] | foundation = England, United Kingdom (1922) | location = Briggella Mills, [[West Yorkshire]], England | key_people = David & Hugh Hield, Founders
Chamsi-Pasha brothers(owners) | industry = [[Manufacturing]], [[Retailing]] | products = [[Cloth]], [[Clothing]], [[Fashion]] | homepage = [http://www.hield.com/ www.hield.com] }} '''Hield Bros''' {{IPAc-en|ˈ|h|iː|l|d}}, or simply '''Hield''', is an English textile manufacturer and retailer of men's clothing and [[Luxury good|luxury]] goods.{{cite web|title=First tailor and weaver partnerships announced for ‘Sheep on the Row’|url=http://www.campaignforwool.org/2015/09/22/first-tailor-and-weaver-partnerships-announced-for-sheep-on-the-row/|website=The Campaign for Wool|accessdate=4 October 2016|date=22 September 2015}} The company was established in 1922. In addition to manufacturing [[cloth]] for its own suits, Hield produces [[cloth]] for many labels and has supplied the [[upholstery]] used in Queen Elizabeth II's custom [[Bentley State Limousine]].{{cite web|url=http://www.royal.gov.uk/TheRoyalHousehold/Transport/Cars.aspx |title=Archived copy |accessdate=20 October 2011 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20111030081356/http://www.royal.gov.uk/TheRoyalHousehold/Transport/Cars.aspx |archivedate=30 October 2011 }} ==History== Founded as the Hield Brothers by David and Hugh Hield in 1922 in [[West Yorkshire]], [[England]], Hield Bros. is based in Briggella Mills, West Yorkshire.{{cite web|title=Our Story|url=http://www.hield.com/history.html|website=Hield Brothers|accessdate=4 October 2016}} The company was acquired by the Chamsi-Pasha family in 1981 when it was under threat of a hostile take-over.{{cite news|last1=Sutcliffe|first1=Robert|title=Holmbridge fabric firm Moxon is the choice of billionaires and royals around the world|url=http://www.examiner.co.uk/news/west-yorkshire-news/holmbridge-fabric-moxon-choice-billionaires-7451870|accessdate=4 October 2016|work=The Huddersfield Daily Examiner|date=18 July 2014}} The company manufactures [[cloth]] for both apparel and [[furniture]], suits, shirts, [[neckties]], knitwear, scarves and throws, [[shoes]], [[luggage]], small leather goods and accessories and has twice been awarded the Queen's Award for Export. [[Forbes]] magazine lists a $21,000 set of 7 Hield suits as one of the "best ways to blow your bonus".{{cite web|url=https://www.forbes.com/2008/01/14/bonus-spend-luxury-forbeslife-cx_ls_0114style_slide_7.html|title=In Pictures: Best Ways To Blow Your Bonus|work=Forbes.com|access-date=14 January 2008}} The company has shops in London's Savile Row, Japan, the Middle East and the USA.{{cite news|last1=Ginns|first1=Bernard|title=Moxon satisfying the global taste for luxury|url=http://www.yorkshirepost.co.uk/news/moxon-satisfying-the-global-taste-for-luxury-1-3724792|accessdate=4 October 2016|work=The Yorkshire Post|date=30 August 2011}} ==Gallery== File:Hield Briggella Mills.jpg|Briggella Mills, West Yorkshire, [[England]] Headquarters of Hield Bros. Ltd. File:Hield Brothers Racing.jpg|Hield-sponsored Le Mans racecar driven by [[United Kingdom|British]] driver Sam Hancock. File:Hield osaka store.jpg|Hield Store in Osaka, Japan. File:Hield Bentley Interior.jpg|Hield Bros. ''Lambswool Sateen'' cloth seen in the interior of Queen [[Elizabeth II of the United Kingdom|Elizabeth II]]'s [[Bentley State Limousine]] ==References== {{reflist}} ==External links== * [http://www.hield.com Official Website] * [https://www.forbes.com/2008/01/14/bonus-spend-luxury-forbeslife-cx_ls_0114style_slide_7.html Forbes: Best Ways To Blow Your Bonus] * [http://www.robbreport.com/Wardrobe-Well-Hield.aspx Robb Report: Well Hield] * [http://www.robbreport.com/Wheels-Her-Majestys-Car.aspx Robb Report: Her Majesty's Car] * [http://www.webmags.co.uk/mag.aspx?magcode=WoolRecord_issue7_4498 Wool Record] [[Category:English brands]] [[Category:Luxury brands]] [[Category:Clothing brands]] [[Category:Clothing retailers]] [[Category:Shops in London]] [[Category:Clothing retailers of England]] [[Category:High fashion brands]] [[Category:Fashion accessory brands]] [[Category:Clothing companies established in 1922]] [[Category:Companies based in Bradford]] [[Category:Textile manufacturers of England]] [[Category:Suit makers]] [[Category:Clothing companies of England]] [[Category:Clothing brands of the United Kingdom]] [[Category:1922 establishments in England]] [[Category:Retail companies established in 1922]] [[Category:Manufacturing companies established in 1922]]
